thread.title: EU Referendum result: Britain votes to LEAVE the European Union in historic vote - Chronicle Live
thread.title_full: EU Referendum result: Britain votes to LEAVE the European Union in historic vote - Chronicle Live

author: Jonathan Walker
title: EU Referendum result: Britain votes to LEAVE the European Union in historic vote - Chronicle Live
text:
EU Referendum result: Britain votes to LEAVE the European Union in historic vote 05:38, 24 Jun 2016 05:38, 24 Jun 2016 By Jonathan Walker The North East leads the way in rejecting European Union membership in Brexit poll, with the majority voting to quit Shares Get daily news by email Britain is set to LEAVE the European Union 
Britain is set to LEAVE the European Union after voters chose Brexit in the historic EU referendum . 
Voters in many parts of the North East rejected the EU. 
Newcastle voted to remain in EU, but only by a small margin - with 50.7% of those voting backing EU membership and 49.3% voting to leave. 
It was the first result to be announced with the exception of Gibraltar, and the narrow victory came as an unpleasant surprise for Remain campaigners, who had expected to win by a larger margin in the city. 
And it was followed a series of decisive victories for the leave campaign across the region. 
In Sunderland, the turnout there was a clear win for the leave campaign, with 61.3% voting to get out of the EU. 
In South Tyneside, 68% voted to leave while in Gateshead 56.8% rejected EU membership. 
The result on North Tyneside was closer , as 53.4%, voted for leave. 
Nationwide it became clear at around 4.45am on Friday as counting continued that the Leave campaign had won, with around 52% of the national vote. BBC analysts calculated it was impossible for the remain campaign to win, based on the votes counted so far. 
The nation’s decision was a victory for the leave campaign backed by Boris Johnson, the senior Conservative seen as the most likely candidate to succeed David Cameron as Tory leader. 
But it was a rejection of Britain’s political establishment, following a referendum campaign in which Mr Cameron, Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, Liberal Democrat Leader Tim Farron and leaders of the Green Party and SNP all pleaded with voters to vote to remain in the EU. 
The Prime Minister was set to make a statement outside 10 Downing Street. Video loading Click to play Tap to play The Live Event you are trying to watch is either unavailable or has not started Please refresh this page in your browser to reload this live event video 
As results began to emerge, Sterling fell - suggesting the financial markets believed the economy would suffer because of the Leave vote. 
What exactly will happen over the next few days is unclear. The referendum result does not mean the UK immediately leaves the EU. 
Mr Cameron is expected to consider over the weekend whether to begin the process of leaving the European Union, which means triggering Article 50 of the Treaty on the European Union - the section which sets out what a member state has to do if they want to go. 
And MPs who supported the Leave campaign want him to take his time, on the basis that it will be important to negotiate the best possible exit deal with the EU. 
But it remains to be seen how long Mr Cameron can remain Prime Minister. 
He personally led the Remain campaign and made a number of visits to the North East during the referendum, including trips to Hitachi in County Durham. 
The result sparked immediate speculation that Mr Cameron would be forced to resign. 
MPs who backed the Remain campaign published a letter as the votes were being counted, insisting the Prime Minister had a “duty” to stay in office however the country voted. Video loading Click to play Tap to play The Live Event you are trying to watch is either unavailable or has not started Please refresh this page in your browser to reload this live event video 
Brexit campaigner Anne Marie Trevelyan, Conservative MP for Berwick in Northumberland, pleaded with Mr Cameron to remain in Downing Street regardless of the result. 
But other Tory Leave campaigners were also said to be angry about Mr Cameron’s tactics during the campaign - particularly what they saw as his decision to authorise a series of personal attacks on Boris Johnson. 
There was even more anger towards George Osborne, the Chancellor, who threatened to introduce a “punishment budget” putting up taxes if the country votes to leave. 
Mr Osborne could move to a different department, possibly the Foreign Office, in a Cabinet reshuffle. 
The result also led to concern within the Labour Party, after many voters in Labour heartlands voted to Leave in EU even though the party had campaigned in favour of membership. 
Tom Watson, Labour’s Deputy Leader, urged Mr Cameron to heal the “divisions” revealed by the referendum campaign. 
“At some points we’ve been slipping into intolerance,” he said. 
And Mr Watson said many people felt they had not shared in the benefits of the economic growth which the UK has enjoyed over the past 30 years. More on the EU Referendum
